abstract.text: An abstraction of a physics body’s solid volume for tuning collision detection.

inlineContent.text: When SceneKit performs contact detection and other simulations for the

objects in your scene, it uses physics shapes instead of the rendered geometry of visible objects. This approach both improves simulation performance and allows you to more easily design your gameplay around scene elements the player can interact with.

When you allow SceneKit to automatically create a physics shape, it uses the simplest possible shape roughly matching the geometry of the node the physics body is attached to. This approach maximizes simulation performance but can lead to unrealistic physics behavior for some objects.

You can make the simulation behave more realistically by defining physics shapes that more closely follow the visible geometry in your scene. This approach comes at a cost to performance, so you want to limit the amount of detail in your physics shapes. Use the highest levels of detail only on bodies for which precise collision detection is important for your app.
If you create a physics shape using one of the basic geometry classes (
), SceneKit uses an idealized form of that geometry for the physics shape instead of using the geometry’s vertex data to simulate collisions. For example, if you create a physics shape from an
object, SceneKit simulates collisions for any object that passes within the sphere’s radius.

Because the idealized forms of simple geometries are computationally much simpler than the vertex data needed for displaying them, using basic geometries for physics shapes (or compound shapes created from basic geometries with the
method) often provides the best balance between simulation accuracy and performance.
Physics shapes are immutable, but you can change the shape associated with a physics body by creating a new
instance and assigning it to the body’s

abstract.text: Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
A six-sided polyhedron geometry whose faces are all rectangles, optionally with rounded edges and corners.
A right circular cylinder geometry whose ends are capped with hemispheres.
A right circular cone or frustum geometry.
A right circular cylinder geometry.
The physics simulation attributes attached to a scene graph node.
An object that defines the solid volume of the physics body for use in collision detection.
An abstraction of a physics body’s solid volume for tuning collision detection.
Keys for the options dictionary used when creating a physics shape.
Creates a physics shape based on a geometry object.
Creates a physics shape from a node or hierarchy of nodes.
Creates a new physics shape by combining others.
The options dictionary that was used to create the shape.
The object that was used to create the shape.
The array of transforms that was used to create a compound shape.
A right rectangular pyramid geometry.
A sphere (or ball or globe) geometry.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
